TITLE: CCU Resident Progress Note
   Chief Complaint: cardiogenic shock
   24 Hour Events:
   - renal came by thought that needed CVVH for fluid removal, had femoral
   line placed to for dialysis
   - respiratory status clinically worsening with respiration to 40s
   - urine lytes Urine urea 169, urine creatinine 132, na < assay, urine
   osm 340, FeNa < 1%
   - urine eos were negative
   - urine lytes: feurea 7% all suggestive of pre-renal etiology likely in
   the setting of poor forward flow with cardiogenic
   - patient intubated in the setting of continued tachycardia  and
   worsening respiratory distress: started neosynephrine prophylactically
   prior to intubation to prevent from dropping pressure
   - started on fentayl and versed for sedation
   - patient got succinylcholine, etomidate as well as 2 x 1mg bolus of
   neo during intubation
   - post intubation chest x-ray demonstrates - ett terminate at thoracic
   inlet 4.5cm from carina, ogt in stomach. other lines stable. slightly
   increased peripheral left interstitial markings suggest mild edema.
   .
   Allergies:
   Codeine
   Unknown;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Heparin Sodium - 1,400 units/hour
   Fentanyl - 50 mcg/hour
   Midazolam (Versed) - 2 mg/hour
   Norepinephrine - 0.03 mcg/Kg/min
   Calcium Gluconate (CRRT) - 1.4 grams/hour
   Other ICU medications:

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:16.3/50.8/1.5, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:2777/149/7.31, ALT / AST:37/272, Alk Phos / T Bili:61/0.5,
   Differential-Neuts:87.3 %, Lymph:6.8 %, Mono:5.6 %, Eos:0.1 %, Lactic
   Acid:1.7 mmol/L, Albumin:3.9 g/dL, LDH:618 IU/L, Ca++:8.1 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.1 mg/dL, PO4:5.8 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM,
   hyperlipidemia and recent fall who presents with nausea and vomiting
   and ongoing CP, found to have elevated CE and EKG changes without any
   acute infarct seen on cardiac catherization.
   .
   # Shock: Presented with hypotension, low CI and extremely elevated
   filling pressures, all consistent with cardiogenic shock.  Also cool
   and clamped down on exam.  Etiology possibly hypotension (unclear
   precipitant) leading to global ischemia and poor CO and elevated
   filling pressures. Patient had balloon pump placed during cardiac
   catherization.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60
   - levofed to maintain blood pressure control for now
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # ARF: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On arrival patient with
   Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal disease.  FeNa 7% and
   feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor forward
   flow in setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Also received
   contrast at OSH, however suspsect that this effect is too early.
   Patient did not put out to lasix drip at maximum doses or Diorel.
   Renal was consulted and recommended starting CVVH in order to remove
   fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Currently appears euvolemic.
   Remains hypoxic, however likely related to splinting in setting of L
   rib fx.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -1 liter per day with CVVH
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele
   .
   # Hypotension: BP ranging in 90s-100s here.  Extremities are cool,
   concerning for cardiogenic shock.  Has evidence of end-organ damage
   with ARF and urine output dropped off despite lasix drip.  Patient had
   intraaortic balloon pump placed in the cath lab.
   - pressors as required to maintain MAP > 60
   - Holding BB for now
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].  On
   procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse <25
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday
   ACCESS: PIV's x 3 (20g x 2, 18g x 1)
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep gtt
   CODE: Full, confirmed with wife [**2-7**] (though pt would not want to be
   maintained on lifelong vent)
   CONTACT: Wife [**Name (NI) 4098**] [**Name (NI) 4099**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4100**] (H), [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4101**] (C)
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

   18 Gauge - [**2190-2-7**] 12:55 AM

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and recent fall, who presents with cardiogenic shock, acute kidney injury, and respiratory distress. He was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to worsening respiratory status. He has been receiving hemodynamic support with norepinephrine and has had a balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion. His renal function is worsening, and he has been started on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) to remove excess fluid.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely due to hypotension, poor forward flow, and global ischemia, which can lead to further organ dysfunction and death if not managed promptly.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's AKI is likely due to hypotension, poor perfusion, and contrast-induced nephropathy, which can worsen if not managed with CVVH and other supportive measures.
3. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory distress is likely due to hypoxia, hypercarbia, and acidosis, which can lead to further organ dysfunction and death if not managed with mechanical ventilation and other supportive measures.
4. Seizures: The patient's history of hyperlipidemia and recent fall may increase his risk of seizures, which can be exacerbated by electrolyte imbalances and other metabolic derangements.
5. Infection: The patient's respiratory and cardiovascular instability may increase his risk of infection, particularly pneumonia and sepsis.
6. Bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and recent fall may increase his risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of anticoagulation therapy.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed with transfusions and other supportive measures.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's history of diabetes and recent stress may increase his risk of hyperglycemia, which can worsen if not managed with insulin therapy and other supportive measures.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's cardiogenic shock, AKI, and respiratory distress require immediate attention and management. The patient should be continued on CVVH, mechanical ventilation, and hemodynamic support with norepinephrine. The patient's blood sugar should be monitored and managed with insulin therapy and other supportive measures. The patient's anemia should be managed with transfusions and other supportive measures. The patient's hyperlipidemia should be managed with atorvastatin 80mg. The patient's recent fall and history of gastrointestinal bleeding may increase his risk of bleeding, which should be monitored and managed with anticoagulation therapy and other supportive measures.

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM,
   hyperlipidemia and recent fall who presents with nausea and vomiting
   and ongoing CP, found to have elevated CE and EKG changes without any
   acute infarct seen on cardiac catherization.
   .
   # Shock: Presented with hypotension, low CI and extremely elevated
   filling pressures, all consistent with cardiogenic shock.  Also cool
   and clamped down on exam.  Etiology possibly hypotension (unclear
   precipitant) leading to global ischemia and poor CO and elevated
   filling pressures. Patient had balloon pump placed during cardiac
   catherization.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60
   - levofed to maintain blood pressure control for now
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # ARF: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On arrival patient with
   Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal disease.  FeNa 7% and
   feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor forward
   flow in setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Also received
   contrast at OSH, however suspsect that this effect is too early.
   Patient did not put out to lasix drip at maximum doses or Diorel.
   Renal was consulted and recommended starting CVVH in order to remove
   fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Currently appears euvolemic.
   Remains hypoxic, however likely related to splinting in setting of L
   rib fx.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -1 liter per day with CVVH
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele
   .
   # Acute liver abnormalities
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect
   secondary to cardiogenic shock.
   -          trend LFTs
   -          continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   -          avoid Tylenol
   -          consider viral hepatitis serologies although low probability
   as previously normal
   # Hypotension: BP ranging in 90s-100s here.  Extremities are cool,
   concerning for cardiogenic shock.  Has evidence of end-organ damage
   with ARF and urine output dropped off despite lasix drip.  Patient had
   intraaortic balloon pump placed in the cath lab.
   - pressors as required to maintain MAP > 60
   - Holding BB for now
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].  On
   procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse <25
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of CAD, DM, hyperlipidemia, and recent fall who presented with cardiogenic shock, nausea, and vomiting. He was found to have elevated troponin levels, EKG changes, and a cardiac catheterization that showed no acute infarct. He was treated with a balloon pump, and his condition has worsened, with continued hypotension, low cardiac output, and elevated filling pressures.

The patient has developed acute renal failure (ARF) with a creatinine level of 3.6 mg/dL, and is being treated with CVVH to remove fluid. He has also developed liver abnormalities, with elevated liver enzymes, and is being treated with pressors to maintain a MAP > 60.

The patient has a history of dilated cardiomyopathy and has undergone cardiac catheterization, which showed 3VD. He has a recent NSTEMI and has been treated with ASA, statin, and heparin drip.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's condition is worsening, and he may require continued treatment with pressors and a balloon pump to maintain a MAP > 60.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is being treated with CVVH to remove fluid. He may require further treatment with dialysis or other renal replacement therapies.
3. Liver abnormalities: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, and he may require further treatment with anticoagulants or other medications to prevent further liver damage.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and he may require further treatment with pressors or other medications to maintain a MAP > 60.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and requires mechanical ventilation. He may require further treatment with respiratory therapy or other medications to improve his lung function.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection, particularly with the use of central lines and other invasive devices.
7. Bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and may be at risk for further bleeding complications.
8. Anemia: The patient has a low hemoglobin level and may require further treatment with blood transfusions or other medications to improve his anemia.

Recommendations:

1. Continue treatment with pressors and a balloon pump to maintain a MAP > 60.
2. Continue CVVH to remove fluid and improve the patient's renal function.
3. Monitor the patient's liver enzymes and adjust treatment as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Continue respiratory therapy and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient for signs of bleeding and adjust treatment as necessary.
8. Consider further treatment with blood transfusions or other medications to improve the patient's anemia.

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM,
   hyperlipidemia and recent fall who presents with nausea and vomiting
   and ongoing CP, found to have elevated CE and EKG changes without
   multivessel disease on cardiac catherization.
   .
   # SHOCK: Presented with hypotension, low CI and extremely elevated
   filling pressures, all consistent with cardiogenic shock.  Also cool
   and clamped down on exam.  Etiology possibly hypotension (unclear
   precipitant) leading to global ischemia and poor CO and elevated
   filling pressures. Patient had balloon pump placed during cardiac
   catherization to augment coronary perfusion.  With balloon pump off
   today SBP maintained in 100s.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60
   - levofed to maintain MAP>60
   - Wean levo as tolerated
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # ARF: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On arrival patient with
   Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal disease.  feNa < 1% on
   urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor forward flow in
   setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Also received contrast at
   OSH, however suspect that this effect is too early. Patient did not put
   out to lasix drip at maximum doses or Diorel.  Renal was consulted and
   started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   Has PA catheter to monitor hemodynamics.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -1 liter per day with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE in am
   - Daily CXR to assess PA cath and balloon location
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele
   .
   # Acute liver abnormalities
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect
   secondary to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   -avoid Tylenol
   - consider viral hepatitis serologies although low probability as
   previously normal
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].  On
   procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse <25
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, nutrition consult for TFs
   ACCESS: PIV's x 3 (20g x 2, 18g x 1), L femoral HD line, R femoral PA
   cath
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep gtt, PPI given intubated
   CODE: Full, confirmed with wife [**2-7**] (though pt would not want to be
   maintained on lifelong vent)

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male who presented with cardiogenic shock, cardiac catheterization revealed 3VD, and recent NSTEMI in the setting of acute GIB. He was intubated due to respiratory distress and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a history of CAD, DM, hyperlipidemia, and dilated cardiomyopathy. His current condition is characterized by hypotension, low cardiac output, and elevated filling pressures. He has been treated with balloon pump, levofed, and has been weaned off beta blocker.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's condition is already critical, and cardiogenic shock can lead to further deterioration, including cardiac arrest, if not managed properly.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels have increased, and he is receiving CVVH to remove fluid. AKI can progress to chronic kidney disease, requiring dialysis, and increasing the risk of cardiovascular events.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, but there is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and respiratory failure.
4. Hemodynamic Instability: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and there is a risk of hypotension or hypertension, which can lead to organ dysfunction.
5. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, and there is a risk of further imbalance, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, including pneumonia, sepsis, and catheter-related infections, which can worsen his condition.
7. Coagulopathy: The patient's PT and PTT are elevated, indicating a risk of bleeding, and his platelet count is low, which can increase the risk of bleeding complications.
8. Liver Dysfunction: The patient's LFTs are abnormal, and there is a risk of further liver damage, which can lead to hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and other complications.
9. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and he is at risk of further anemia, which can lead to cardiovascular complications.
10. Malnutrition: The patient is at risk of malnutrition due to his inability to eat and his prolonged stay in the ICU, which can lead to further complications, including impaired wound healing and increased risk of infections.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM,
   hyperlipidemia and recent fall who presents with nausea and vomiting
   and ongoing CP, found to have elevated CE and EKG changes without
   multivessel disease on cardiac catherization.
   .
   # SHOCK: Presented with hypotension, low CI and extremely elevated
   filling pressures, all consistent with cardiogenic shock.  Also cool
   and clamped down on exam.  Etiology possibly hypotension (unclear
   precipitant) leading to global ischemia and poor CO and elevated
   filling pressures. Patient had balloon pump placed during cardiac
   catherization to augment coronary perfusion.  With balloon pump off
   today SBP maintained in 100s.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60
   - levofed to maintain MAP>60
   - Wean levo as tolerated
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # ARF: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On arrival patient with
   Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal disease.  feNa < 1% on
   urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor forward flow in
   setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Also received contrast at
   OSH, however suspect that this effect is too early. Patient did not put
   out to lasix drip at maximum doses or Diorel.  Renal was consulted and
   started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   Has PA catheter to monitor hemodynamics.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -1 liter per day with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE in am
   - Daily CXR to assess PA cath and balloon location
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele
   .
   # Acute liver abnormalities
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect
   secondary to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   -avoid Tylenol
   - consider viral hepatitis serologies although low probability as
   previously normal
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].  On
   procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse <25
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of CAD, MI, DM, hyperlipidemia, and recent fall who presents with cardiogenic shock, acute renal failure, and pulmonary edema. He was intubated due to worsening respiratory status and has been on mechanical ventilation. His cardiac catheterization revealed no evidence of acute infarct, but significant global LV dysfunction. He has been treated with balloon pump, levofed, and aspirin to maintain MAP >60 and has been started on CVVH for fluid removal.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely due to hypotension and poor forward flow in the setting of heart failure. He requires continued balloon pump support, levofed to maintain MAP >60, and monitoring of his hemodynamics.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to hypotension, poor forward flow, and cardiogenic shock. He requires continued CVVH for fluid removal, follow-up daily renal recommendations, and avoidance of nephrotoxins.
3. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's pulmonary edema is likely due to cardiogenic shock and requires continued ventilator support and monitoring of his oxygenation.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease and requires continued follow-up with his primary care physician and repeat iron studies.
5. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia is likely due to his history of CAD and requires continued treatment with atorvastatin.
6. Peripheral Neuropathy: The patient's peripheral neuropathy is likely due to his history of gabapentin use and requires restarting once he is stable.
7. Liver Abnormalities: The patient's liver abnormalities are likely due to cardiogenic shock and require continued monitoring of his liver function tests.

Recommendations:

1. Continue balloon pump support and levofed to maintain MAP >60.
2. Continue CVVH for fluid removal and monitor the patient's hemodynamics.
3. Monitor the patient's oxygenation and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
4. Continue aspirin, statin, and atorvastatin therapy.
5. Restart gabapentin once the patient is stable.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function tests and adjust therapy as needed.
7. Follow up with the patient's primary care physician to monitor his anemia and hyperlipidemia.

Note: The patient's code status is full code, and his family member has been informed of his condition and treatment plan.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a recent fall. The patient presents with cardiogenic shock, septic shock, acute respiratory distress syndrome, acute kidney injury, and acute hepatitis.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 101.8°F (38.8°C)
* Blood pressure: 88/53 mmHg
* Heart rate: 89 beats per minute
* Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 9.8 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 153 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 3.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 25.4 mmol/L
* Glucose: 101 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.2 mmol/L
* Troponin-T: 7.31 ng/mL
* CK-MB: 149 ng/mL
* ALT: 2737 IU/L
* AST: 4183 IU/L
* Alkaline phosphatase: 70 IU/L
* Total bilirubin: 0.8 mg/dL
* Albumin: 3.2 g/dL
* LDH: 5796 IU/L
* Calcium: 9.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.3 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Cardiogenic shock
* Septic shock
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome
* Acute kidney injury
* Acute hepatitis
* Diabetes mellitus, type II
* Hyperlipidemia
* Coronary artery disease
* Recent fall

The patient's medications include:

* Aspirin
* Statin
* Hepatitis B immune globulin
* Low-molecular-weight heparin
* Vancomycin
* Piperacillin-tazobactam
* Fentanyl
* Midazolam
* Lansoprazole
* Calcium gluconate
* Vasopressin

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Cardiac catheterization to assess coronary artery disease
* Balloon pump to augment coronary perfusion
* Vasopressin to support blood pressure
* Fentanyl and midazolam to manage pain and anxiety
* Vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam to treat septicemia
* CVVH to remove fluid and waste products
* Diuretics to manage fluid overload
* Insulin to manage blood glucose levels
* Prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection

The patient's potential complications include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Respiratory failure
* Renal failure
* Hepatic failure
* Sepsis
* Shock
* Infection

The patient's disposition is to the intensive care unit (ICU) for continued monitoring and treatment.

   Assessment and Plan
   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization.
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK: Presented with hypotension, low CI and extremely
   elevated filling pressures, all consistent with cardiogenic shock.
   Also cool and clamped down on exam.  Patient had balloon pump placed
   during cardiac catherization to augment coronary perfusion.  With
   balloon pump off SBP maintained in 100s.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60 and goal CI 2.0
   - Switched levofed to vasopressin [**1-25**] recurrent ventricular ectopy with
   a non-perfusing NSVT
   - Cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock
   .
   # SEPSIS: Pt with GPC bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once off levophed PVR <
   WNL consistent with a distributive shock. Given ongoing bacteremia
   there is likely a component of septic shock.
   - Continue screening BCx until cleared
   - Empiric vanco + pip/tazo dosed for CVVH
   - Investigate sources for infection. Has thrombophlebitis on R hand. ?
   Aspiration PNA. Lines are new but may be source of infection
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall + pulmonary
   edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory distress and
   tiring from effort
   - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # ARF: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On arrival patient with
   Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal disease.  feNa < 1% on
   urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor forward flow in
   setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Also received contrast at
   OSH, however suspect that this effect is too early. Patient did not put
   out to lasix drip at maximum doses or Diorel.  Renal was consulted and
   started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   Has PA catheter to monitor hemodynamics.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE pending to assess cardiac function
   - Daily CXR to assess PA cath and balloon location
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].  On
   procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse <25
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, nutrition consult for TFs

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and recent fall with nausea and vomiting. The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and acute renal failure. 

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 101.8°F (38.8°C)
* Blood pressure: 88/53 mmHg
* Heart rate: 89 bpm
* Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 10 mmHg, PAP 39/21 mmHg, CO/CI 4.3 L/min/2 L/min/m²

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 9.8 K/μL
* Hematocrit: 29%
* Platelet count: 153 K/μL
* Creatinine: 3.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 20 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.2 mmol/L
* Alanine aminotransferase: 2737 IU/L
* Aspartate aminotransferase: 4183 IU/L
* Albumin: 3.2 g/dL
* Calcium: 9.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.3 mg/dL

The patient has been treated with various medications, including vasopressin, levophed, and antibiotics. The patient is also receiving continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) and has been intubated due to respiratory distress.

The patient's medical complications include cardiogenic shock, septic shock, acute renal failure, and acute hepatitis. The patient is at risk for further complications, including respiratory failure, cardiac arrhythmias, and bleeding.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Adjustment of medications as needed
* Continued CVVH and hemodynamic support
* Further investigation into the source of infection
* Consideration of further interventions, such as cardiac catheterization or surgery

The patient's code status is "full," and the patient's wife has been notified.

   Assessment and Plan
   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization.
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK:
   - Shock picture now is a combination of cardiogenic with
   distributative.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60 and goal CI 2.0, if
   possible, will try to wean down to 2:1 though his MAPS this
     morning are only in the low 60s.
   - Switched levofed to vasopressin [**1-25**] recurrent ventricular ectopy with
   a non-perfusing NSVT, consider adding levophed back if
      needed
   - Cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock
   .
   # SEPSIS/BACTEREMIA: Pt with GPC bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once off
   levophed PVR < WNL consistent with a distributive shock. Given ongoing
   bacteremia there is likely a component of septic shock.
   - Continue screening BCx until cleared
   - Empiric vanco + pip/tazo dosed for CVVH
   - Investigate sources for infection. Has thrombophlebitis on R hand. ?
   Aspiration PNA. Lines are new but may be source of infection. Will try
   and get PA line out.
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA:
   Ongoing Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall +
   pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory
   distress and tiring from effort. Now with left sided infiltrate and
   sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip
   - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs, improving
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # Acute Kidney Injury: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On
   arrival patient with Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal
   disease.  feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor
   forward flow in setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Renal was
   consulted and started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   Has PA catheter to monitor hemodynamics.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE pending to assess cardiac function (planned for today)
   - Daily CXR to assess PA cath and balloon location
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele, less ectopy.
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # ANEMIA (CKD): Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].
   On procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse this morning (<25)
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, nutrition consult for TFs
   ACCESS: PIV's x 3 (20g x 2, 18g x 1), L femoral HD line, R femoral PA
   cath
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep gtt, PPI given intubated

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and recent falls. He was admitted with nausea and vomiting, and was found to have elevated creatine kinase (CK) and electrocardiogram (EKG) changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization.

The patient's current condition is complicated by cardiogenic shock, septic shock, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), acute hepatitis, and acute kidney injury (AKI). He is receiving multiple medications, including vasopressors, antibiotics, and anticoagulants.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: Continued deterioration of cardiac function, worsening of hypotension, and potential cardiac arrest.
2. Septic shock: Continued progression of sepsis, worsening of organ dysfunction, and potential death.
3. VAP: Development of respiratory failure, worsening of oxygenation, and potential need for tracheostomy.
4. Acute hepatitis: Continued liver damage, worsening of liver function, and potential need for liver transplantation.
5. AKI: Continued kidney damage, worsening of electrolyte imbalance, and potential need for dialysis.
6. Sepsis-related complications: Development of septic shock, organ dysfunction, and potential death.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: Development of ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, or atrial fibrillation, which can worsen cardiac function and increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
8. Respiratory failure: Development of respiratory failure, worsening of oxygenation, and potential need for mechanical ventilation.
9. Neurological complications: Development of seizures, stroke, or encephalopathy, which can worsen neurological function and increase the risk of death.

To manage these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring of his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies. He should receive aggressive treatment for his cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and VAP, including vasopressors, antibiotics, and anticoagulants. He should also receive supportive care, including oxygen therapy, mechanical ventilation, and dialysis, as needed.

   Assessment and Plan
   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization.
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK:
   - Shock picture now is a combination of cardiogenic with
   distributative.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60 and goal CI 2.0, if
   possible, will try to wean down to 2:1 though his MAPS this
     morning are only in the low 60s.
   - Switched levofed to vasopressin [**1-25**] recurrent ventricular ectopy with
   a non-perfusing NSVT, consider adding levophed back if
      needed
   - Cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock
   .
   # SEPSIS/BACTEREMIA: Pt with GPC bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once off
   levophed PVR < WNL consistent with a distributive shock. Given ongoing
   bacteremia there is likely a component of septic shock.
   - Continue screening BCx until cleared
   - Empiric vanco + pip/tazo dosed for CVVH
   - Investigate sources for infection. Has thrombophlebitis on R hand. ?
   Aspiration PNA. Lines are new but may be source of infection. Will try
   and get PA line out.
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA:
   Ongoing Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall +
   pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory
   distress and tiring from effort. Now with left sided infiltrate and
   sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip
   - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs, improving
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # Acute Kidney Injury: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On
   arrival patient with Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal
   disease.  feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor
   forward flow in setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Renal was
   consulted and started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   Has PA catheter to monitor hemodynamics.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE pending to assess cardiac function (planned for today)
   - Daily CXR to assess PA cath and balloon location
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele, less ectopy.
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # ANEMIA (CKD): Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].
   On procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse this morning (<25)
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .

   11:46 ------<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and recent fall. He was admitted to the ICU with cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and acute kidney injury.

The patient's condition has been complicated by the development of ventricular ectopy, non-perfusing ventricular tachycardia, and recurrent shock. He has also developed respiratory distress, requiring intubation, and has a left-sided infiltrate on chest X-ray.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated creatinine and lactate levels, indicating acute kidney injury and sepsis. His liver function tests are abnormal, with elevated transaminases and bilirubin levels, suggesting possible liver injury.

The patient's medication regimen includes vasopressin, levophed, and vancomycin, as well as other medications to manage his underlying conditions. He is also receiving CVVH to remove fluid and waste products.

The patient's plan of care includes continued CVVH, continued antibiotics, and monitoring of his hemodynamic status. He will also require ongoing management of his respiratory and cardiac status, as well as monitoring of his liver and kidney function.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: Continued hypotension and decreased cardiac output can lead to further organ dysfunction and death.
2. Sepsis: Failure to control the underlying infection can lead to further organ dysfunction and death.
3. Acute kidney injury: Continued hypotension and decreased renal perfusion can lead to further kidney damage and potential need for dialysis.
4. Respiratory failure: Continued respiratory distress can lead to further respiratory failure and potential need for mechanical ventilation.
5. Liver injury: Continued liver dysfunction can lead to further liver damage and potential need for liver transplantation.
6. Anemia: Continued blood loss and decreased erythropoietin production can lead to further anemia and potential need for blood transfusions.
7. Hyperlipidemia: Continued high cholesterol levels can lead to further cardiovascular disease and potential need for lipid-lowering therapy.
8. Peripheral neuropathy: Continued nerve damage can lead to further numbness, weakness, and potential need for physical therapy.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing management of his cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and acute kidney injury. He will require close monitoring of his hemodynamic status, respiratory status, and laboratory results to prevent further complications and optimize his care.

   Assessment and Plan
   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization.
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK: Presented with hypotension, low CI and extremely
   elevated filling pressures, all consistent with cardiogenic shock.
   Also cool and clamped down on exam.  Patient had balloon pump placed
   during cardiac catherization to augment coronary perfusion.  With
   balloon pump off SBP maintained in 100s.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60 and goal CI 2.0
   - Switched levofed to vasopressin [**1-25**] recurrent ventricular ectopy with
   a non-perfusing NSVT
   - Cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock
   .
   # SEPSIS: Pt with GPC bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once off levophed PVR <
   WNL consistent with a distributive shock. Given ongoing bacteremia
   there is likely a component of septic shock.
   - Continue screening BCx until cleared
   - Empiric vanco + pip/tazo dosed for CVVH
   - Investigate sources for infection. Has thrombophlebitis on R hand. ?
   Aspiration PNA. Lines are new but may be source of infection
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall + pulmonary
   edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory distress and
   tiring from effort
   - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # ARF: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On arrival patient with
   Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal disease.  feNa < 1% on
   urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor forward flow in
   setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Also received contrast at
   OSH, however suspect that this effect is too early. Patient did not put
   out to lasix drip at maximum doses or Diorel.  Renal was consulted and
   started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   Has PA catheter to monitor hemodynamics.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE pending to assess cardiac function
   - Daily CXR to assess PA cath and balloon location
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].  On
   procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse <25
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, nutrition consult for TFs
   ACCESS: PIV's x 3 (20g x 2, 18g x 1), L femoral HD line, R femoral PA
   cath
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep gtt, PPI given intubated
   CODE: Full, confirmed with wife [**2-7**] (though pt would not want to be
   maintained on lifelong vent)
   CONTACT: Wife [**Name (NI) 4098**] [**Name (NI) 4099**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4100**] (H), [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4101**] (C)

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of CAD, DM, and hyperlipidemia who presented with nausea and vomiting, and was found to have cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and acute renal failure. He was intubated due to respiratory distress and has a history of recent NSTEMI and GIB. He has been treated with vasopressin, vancomycin, and Zosyn, and is being managed with CVVH and mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock, which increases the risk of cardiac arrest and mortality.
2. Septic shock: The patient's septic shock is caused by GPC bacteremia, which may lead to further organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely caused by hypotension, poor forward flow in the setting of heart failure, and cardiogenic shock, which increases the risk of chronic kidney disease and dialysis dependence.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is complicated by pulmonary edema, which may lead to further respiratory distress and failure.
5. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is complicated by the presence of GPC bacteremia, which may lead to further organ dysfunction and failure.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular instability is complicated by the presence of cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and acute renal failure, which increases the risk of cardiac arrest and mortality.
7. Infection: The patient's infection is complicated by the presence of GPC bacteremia, which may lead to further organ dysfunction and failure.
8. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hemodynamic instability is complicated by the presence of cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and acute renal failure, which increases the risk of cardiac arrest and mortality.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan are as follows:

1. Continue to manage the patient's cardiogenic shock with vasopressin and CVVH.
2. Continue to manage the patient's septic shock with vancomycin and Zosyn.
3. Continue to manage the patient's acute renal failure with CVVH and renal replacement therapy.
4. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and pulmonary edema treatment.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular stability and hemodynamic parameters.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's infection and sepsis, and treat accordingly.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as necessary.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular stability and adjust treatment as necessary.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to closely monitor the patient's cardiovascular stability and hemodynamic parameters.
2. Continue to closely monitor the patient's infection and sepsis, and treat accordingly.
3. Continue to closely monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as necessary.
4. Continue to closely monitor the patient's respiratory failure and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Continue to closely monitor the patient's cardiovascular instability and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Consider consulting a nephrologist for further management of the patient's acute renal failure.
7. Consider consulting a cardiologist for further management of the patient's cardiogenic shock and septic shock.
8. Consider consulting an infectious disease specialist for further management of the patient's sepsis.

Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   - ID recs: switch from Zosyn to Levofloxacin for better coverage of
   Moraxella Catarrhalis in sputum, continue Vanc, add Gentamycin for
   synergistic effect in case endocarditis. Also daily BCx x2, TEE to r/o
   endocarditis when able (not ordered yet)
   - RIJ placed. During this pt had small run of V-tach with rate 110s,
   improved after carotid massage to 70s. Likely related to guidewire
   removal.
   - Renal replaced L femoral CVVH line with L IJ. Line was short, so will
   be exchanged today.
   - R femoral Swann-Ganz and sheath removed, as well as L femoral CVVH
   line
   - Heparin resumed while on 1:2
   - Low-dose Dopamine had been added to Vasopressin for BP support.
   Planned to wean off IABP then pressors, but overnight at 3:45a had a
   ~20min run of V-tach with HR in 60s, MAPS down to 60s, lytes were wnl.
   Pt was sleeping at the time. IABP was switched back to 1:1 for
   improvement of MAPS. Responded to carotid massage with return of sinus
   rhythm, HR back down to 70s, MAPS up to 70s-80s.
   - Micro lab says Staph sensitivities will return in am
   - Pt received 1 unit pRBC without incident, post-transfusion crit 26.3
   from 24.4, now this am down to 25.8
   - Repeat ECHO not done yet
   - Vanc trough pending for am
   Allergies:
   Codeine
   Unknown;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) - [**2190-2-9**] 12:00 PM
   Vancomycin - [**2190-2-9**] 02:50 PM

   Assessment and Plan
   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization.
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK:
   - Shock picture now is a combination of cardiogenic with
   distributative.
   - Low-dose Dopamine added to Vasopressin yest for BP support -
   Cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock
 currently off
   dopamine since 3AM, IABP weaned to 3:1
   -
   .
   # SEPSIS/BACTEREMIA: Coag + S. aureus bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once
   off levophed PVR < WNL consistent with a distributive shock.
   - Continue daily surveillance blood cultures
   - Continue vanco + low dose gent dosed for CVVH
   - Continue levaquin for Morexella in sputum
   - Appreciate ID recs
   - Lines changed yest with HD line changed and PA sheath pulled. Unable
   to wean off IABP
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA:
   Ongoing Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall +
   pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory
   distress and tiring from effort. Now with left sided infiltrate and
   sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip
   - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   - Continue Vanc/levo per ID recs
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs, improving
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # Acute Kidney Injury: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On
   arrival patient with Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal
   disease.  feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor
   forward flow in setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Renal was
   consulted and started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele, less ectopy.
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # ANEMIA (CKD): Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].
   On procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse yest 1U PRBC for HCT <25
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, nutrition consult for TFs
   ACCESS: PIV's x 3 (20g x 2, 18g x 1), L IJ HD line, R IJ
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep gtt, PPI given intubated
   CODE: Full, confirmed with wife [**2-7**] (though pt would not want to be
   maintained on lifelong vent)
   CONTACT: Wife [**Name (NI) 4098**] [**Name (NI) 4099**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4100**] (H), [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4101**] (C)
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren Renal (Full) - [**2190-2-9**] 09:30 PM 20 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2190-2-7**] 12:55 AM
   IABP line - [**2190-2-7**] 04:50 AM
   Sheath - [**2190-2-7**] 05:27 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2190-2-9**] 04:37 PM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2190-2-9**] 06:52 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  heparin
   Stress ulcer:  PPI gtt
   VAP:  bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:  Full
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of CAD, DM, hyperlipidemia, and recent fall who presented with nausea, vomiting, and ongoing chest pain. He was found to have elevated CPK and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock with distributive shock, septic shock, and acute kidney injury. He has a history of NSTEMI, and his biomarkers are trending up. He has a balloon pump in place to increase coronary perfusion. The patient is intubated and on CVVH.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock, and he requires continued pressor support to maintain adequate blood pressure.
2. Sepsis/Bacteremia: The patient has a coagulase-positive Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia, which needs to be monitored and treated with antibiotics.
3. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia: The patient has ongoing respiratory distress and a left-sided infiltrate, which requires continued intubation and treatment with antibiotics.
4. Acute Hepatitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may be secondary to cardiogenic shock or sepsis. He requires close monitoring and treatment with antiviral medications if necessary.
5. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient has acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 3.6 mg/dL. He requires continued CVVH and close monitoring of his kidney function.
6. Coronary Artery Disease: The patient has a history of CAD, and his biomarkers are trending up, indicating ongoing myocardial infarction. He requires continued treatment with aspirin, statin, and heparin.
7. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease, which requires treatment with iron and blood transfusions.
8. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia, which requires treatment with atorvastatin.
9. Peripheral Neuropathy: The patient has peripheral neuropathy, which requires treatment with gabapentin once he is stable.
10. Pneumonia: The patient has pneumonia, which requires treatment with antibiotics and close monitoring of his respiratory status.

Recommendations:

1. Continue cardiogenic shock treatment with pressors and CVVH.
2. Monitor and treat sepsis/bacteremia with antibiotics and close monitoring of his blood cultures.
3. Continue ventilator-associated pneumonia treatment with antibiotics and close monitoring of his respiratory status.
4. Monitor and treat acute hepatitis with antiviral medications if necessary.
5. Continue acute kidney injury treatment with CVVH and close monitoring of his kidney function.
6. Continue coronary artery disease treatment with aspirin, statin, and heparin.
7. Treat anemia of chronic disease with iron and blood transfusions.
8. Treat hyperlipidemia with atorvastatin.
9. Restart gabapentin once the patient is stable.
10. Monitor and treat pneumonia with antibiotics and close monitoring of his respiratory status.

   Assessment and Plan
   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization.
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK:
   - Shock picture now is a combination of cardiogenic with
   distributative.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60 and goal CI 2.0, if
   possible, will try to wean down to 2:1 though his MAPS this
     morning are only in the low 60s.
   - Switched levofed to vasopressin [**1-25**] recurrent ventricular ectopy with
   a non-perfusing NSVT, consider adding levophed back if
      needed
   - Cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock
   .
   # SEPSIS/BACTEREMIA: Pt with GPC bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once off
   levophed PVR < WNL consistent with a distributive shock. Given ongoing
   bacteremia there is likely a component of septic shock.
   - Continue screening BCx until cleared
   - Empiric vanco + pip/tazo dosed for CVVH
   - Investigate sources for infection. Has thrombophlebitis on R hand. ?
   Aspiration PNA. Lines are new but may be source of infection. Will try
   and get PA line out.
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA:
   Ongoing Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall +
   pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory
   distress and tiring from effort. Now with left sided infiltrate and
   sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip
   - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs, improving
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # Acute Kidney Injury: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On
   arrival patient with Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal
   disease.  feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor
   forward flow in setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Renal was
   consulted and started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   Has PA catheter to monitor hemodynamics.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE pending to assess cardiac function (planned for today)
   - Daily CXR to assess PA cath and balloon location
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele, less ectopy.
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # ANEMIA (CKD): Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].
   On procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse this morning (<25)
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, nutrition consult for TFs
   ACCESS: PIV's x 3 (20g x 2, 18g x 1), L femoral HD line, R femoral PA

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of CAD, DM, and hyperlipidemia, who presents with nausea and vomiting, ongoing chest pain, and cardiogenic shock. He has undergone cardiac catheterization and has been treated with balloon pump, vasopressin, and CVVH. He has also been diagnosed with septic shock, ventricular tachycardia, and acute hepatitis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock, which may worsen his condition.
2. Septic Shock: The patient's septic shock is likely caused by his bacteremia and may lead to further organ dysfunction.
3. Ventricular Tachycardia: The patient's recurrent ventricular tachycardia may indicate a life-threatening arrhythmia that requires prompt treatment.
4. Acute Hepatitis: The patient's acute hepatitis may worsen his liver function and increase his risk of bleeding and infection.
5. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen his kidney function and increase his risk of dialysis dependence.
6. Coronary Artery Disease: The patient's coronary artery disease may worsen his cardiac function and increase his risk of myocardial infarction.
7. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's pulmonary edema may worsen his respiratory function and increase his risk of respiratory failure.
8. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia: The patient's ventilator-associated pneumonia may worsen his respiratory function and increase his risk of sepsis.
9. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen his oxygen delivery and increase his risk of organ dysfunction.
10. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may worsen his cardiovascular risk and increase his risk of myocardial infarction.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, cardiac function, and respiratory status, and to adjust his treatment plan accordingly.

   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization.
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK:
   - Shock picture now is a combination of cardiogenic with
   distributative.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60 and goal CI 2.0, if
   possible, will try to wean down to 2:1 though his MAPS this
     morning are only in the low 60s.
   - Switched levofed to vasopressin [**1-25**] recurrent ventricular ectopy with
   a non-perfusing NSVT, consider adding levophed back if
      needed
   - Cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock
   .
   # SEPSIS/BACTEREMIA: Pt with GPC bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once off
   levophed PVR < WNL consistent with a distributive shock. Given ongoing
   bacteremia there is likely a component of septic shock.
   - Continue screening BCx until cleared
   - Empiric vanco + pip/tazo dosed for CVVH
   - Investigate sources for infection. Has thrombophlebitis on R hand. ?
   Aspiration PNA. Lines are new but may be source of infection. Will try
   and get PA line out.
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA:
   Ongoing Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall +
   pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory
   distress and tiring from effort. Now with left sided infiltrate and
   sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip
   - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs, improving
